Herein, Aquivion®/oxide hybrid catalysts were prepared by an innovative spray freeze-drying method, tuning acid site distribution in the materials and exploring an approach to GVL synthesis from furfuryl alcohol (FAL) by employing non-noble metals. SiO2, TiO2 and ZrO2 were selected because of their increasing Lewis acidity, a key factor in promoting catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH). A thorough study on thermal stability through TGA, MAS NMR, porosimetry, SEM-EDX and experimental testing unveiled their resistance to thermal treatments and its influence on catalytic performances. In this study, it is shown how the optimal thermal treatment conditions for the composite materials vary depending on the acid properties of the supporting oxide. The environmental challenges we are recently facing dictate a reduction in the use of fossil-based resources in favor of renewable ones. In this scenario, biorefineries based on renewable resources such as lignocellulosic materials, represent a promising low-carbon alternative for conventional fossil-based chemistry [1–3]. Among all the possible molecules that can be derived from biomasses, furfuryl alcohol (FAL) is gaining increasing attention [4]. It can be easily obtained after the reduction of furfural (FU), a widely known molecule that can in turn be produced as a result of hydrolysis and dehydration of hemicellulose [5,6]. The conversion of furfuryl alcohol to γ-valerolactone (GVL) is an especially attractive reaction given the unique features of the latter. Indeed, GVL can be considered as a non-toxic and versatile platform molecule from which it is possible to obtain a wide range of products such as solvents, monomers for the polymer industry, fuel additives, etc [7–9]. The GVL production from FAL consists of a cascade reaction ( Fig. 1a) involving acid-catalyzed steps and hydrogenation steps. In order to avoid the use of molecular hydrogen that nowadays is mainly obtained from the steam reforming of methane, one possibility is to employ the Catalytic Transfer Hydrogenation reaction (CTH). This approach involves the use of an alcohol as the hydrogen donor capable of reducing the carbonyl group of the substrate. As reported in numerous studies, Lewis acid sites (LAS) are needed in order to promote the CTH reaction [10–14]. By viewing the reaction scheme proposed in Fig. 1a it is therefore possible to distinguish two different types of steps: those catalyzed by Brønsted acid sites (BAS) (red arrows) and those requiring Lewis acid sites to proceed (blue arrows). A catalyst capable of promoting the whole cascade reaction must have both types of functionalities. Up to date, various catalysts with optimized acid-base properties were tested [15]. As an example, Zr-doped zeolites or mesoporous aluminosilicates proved to be capable of converting levulinates to GVL thanks to the coexistence of BAS on the zeolitic framework and LAS provided by the zirconium atoms [16–24]. Nevertheless, those types of catalysts also showed some limitations, especially in the hydrolytic ring opening steps. A novel class of materials such acid polymers can be effectively used to boost the Brønsted acidity of the material and overcome the limitations of previous catalytic systems. One of the first acid polymer to be used in catalysis was Amberlyst® [25]. It is the sulfonated copolymer of styrene and divinylbenzene and has also been used on an industrial scale in the isobutene coupling or biodiesel synthesis [26–28]. Nevertheless, Amberlyst® has also some drawbacks, such as its low thermal stability (it can only be used up to 150–180 °C) and its low surface area, which makes acid sites poorly accessible.[29,30] To improve thermal resistance, fluorinated polymer such as Chemours Nafion® and Syensqo produced Aquivion®, can be used. In particular, Aquivion® (Fig. 1b), a short side chains superacid polymer that can be obtained with the copolymerization of tetrafluoroethylene and sulfonyl fluoride vinyl ether (SFVE) followed by an alkaline hydrolysis and acidification of the functional group introducing the -SO3H functionality, have attracted the interest of researchers for its higher thermal and chemical stability compared to the commercially available congeners [31]. Although thermal stability and superacid characteristics of Aquivion® PFSA can be successfully applied to catalyze different reactions, its activity was demonstrated to strongly depend on the number of accessible acid sites and on material shaping [32–35]. To increase the active surface area and accessibility to acid sites, also reaching the goal to decrease the usage of expensive resin, the polymer can be dispersed on an oxide. Schiaroli et al. used an Aquivion®/SiO2 nanocomposites obtained through sol-gel synthesis for the selective acylation of 1,2-methylenedioxybenzene with propionic anhydride. The material proved to be more active and selective with respect to the bare polymer, reaching a conversion of 53 % and a selectivity toward the product of interest of 83 % [35]. In addition, the preparation of multicomponent polymer–inorganic materials opens up broad possibilities for the design of different functional properties of the composite catalyst, due to the possible variation of parameters such us the acidic properties of the oxide materials. To synthesize hybrid organic–inorganic materials various approaches can be used, and the catalytic activity is strongly correlated with the efficiency of the method of preparation. Interesting approaches to develop a one-step synthesis of polymeric-inorganic materials with well-controlled compositions and porous textures are spray techniques [36–38]. Debecker et al. demonstrated the possibility to combine aerosol spray drying and sol-gel chemistry proving the effectiveness of this process for the preparation of a wide range oxide-based catalysts [38,39]. We have already demonstrated the possibility of preparing composite materials through a similar approach which employs the heterocoagulation and spray-freeze-drying (SFD) of sols containing the precursor of the active phases [31,40]. This process exploits the electrostatic self-assembly between the oxide colloidal phase and the Aquivion® polymer dispersion. Moreover, we have also demonstrated [31,41–43] that with this procedure, they can be dried at low temperatures to produce spherical porous particles and forming high-surface area systems. In our previous paper, we reported the use of Spray Freeze Drying (SFD) as an innovative and effective technique for the preparation of Aquivion®-oxide composite materials for the cascade reaction from furfuryl alcohol to GVL.[40] In particular, the investigation of an array of these composites focused on their catalytic performances led to a previously unreported productivity of 4470 µmolGVL gCat −1 h−1 at a temperature of 180 °C. In the present paper, the focus was instead devoted to the correlation between catalyst properties and catalytic results, as well as their stability and resistance to thermal treatments. Firstly, we selected SiO2, which has no appreciable Lewis acidity as the reference material to better investigate the Aquivion® behavior in a SFD composite material, and to investigate the effect of the thermal treatment. A series of catalysts with different Aquivion® content (20 %, 30 %, and 40 %) were synthesized and tested in order to find the best composition. Thereafter, new composite materials were prepared by varying the oxide. TiO2 and ZrO2 were chosen as oxides with increasing Lewis acidity in order to investigate the physico-chemical properties and thermal stability of the composite materials obtained. A detailed characterization of the catalysts by means of ζ-potential measurements, ThermoGravimetric Analysis (TGA), Scanning Electron Microscopy-Energy Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy (SEM-EDX), N2 adsorption-desorption, Magic Angle Spinning-Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (MAS NMR) and Temperature Programmed Desorption (TPD) were performed together with catalytic tests in the FAL conversion to GVL. The results shed light on the thermal resistance of the catalysts and their catalytic behavior upon calcination. Moreover, the synthetic procedure proved to be an easy and feasible way to prepare tunable Aquivion®-oxide composite materials that can be properly modified to selectively obtain the desired product, IPL or GVL, of the cascade reaction, while minimizing the undesired one (FPE, AnL) through the proper tuning between BAS/LAS acid sites. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Composite materials preparation The spray freeze-drying of the composites requires the preparation of a water suspension of the phases involved in the synthesis with a total concentration of solids of 20 wt%. While Aquivion® (D79–25BS water-based dispersion, solid content: 25 wt%, polymer acid loading: 1.25 mmol/g corresponding to an Equivalent Weight -EW- of 790 g/mol) only required 1:1 dilution in distilled water before being added dropwise to the water suspension of the metal oxide that is to be part of the final composite, the second component required better control. In the case of silica Ludox HS-40 water suspension, acidification was required to remove the stabilizing sodium ions on its surface to promote coagulation after the spray process. This was achieved by adding Dowex 50 W X8 proton exchange resin under vigorous stirring and monitoring the pH. Once the pH value reached 4, the resin was removed via filtration to leave the silica suspension ready for mixing with Aquivion®. In the case of zirconia and titania, previously synthesized and calcined at 500 °C, the oxidic powder was suspended in water, then the pH was measured to ensure it was at or below 4. If necessary, small corrections could be made by adding small amounts of 0.1 M HCl water solution. The suspension was then subjected to 15 min of sonication to properly disperse the powder. Once the oxide suspension was properly treated according to the previous procedures, Aquivion® was added dropwise under vigorous stirring, then the mixed suspension was transferred into a polypropylene bottle. Zirconia milling balls (5 mm diameter) were added to the level of the dispersion, then the suspension was subjected to 24 h of ball milling at approximately 10 rpm. After 24 h, the milling balls were removed, and the ζ-potential of the suspension was measured to ensure that the heterocoagulation of the phases was properly achieved. The suspension was then utilized for the spray-freeze drying. The spray-freeze drying process was carried out in a Lab-scale Granulator LS-2 (PowderPro AB), as represented in Fig. 2. The suspension was co-fed to a nozzle along with a nitrogen flow at 0.4 bar to achieve proper atomization, then directed onto a liquid nitrogen bath to instantly freeze the droplets into solid granules. The frozen granules were then transferred to a lyophilizer (LYO GT 2, SRK System Technik) to sublimate water. The resulting materials were afterwards calcined under static air to ensure consolidation of the structure. A ramp of 2 °C/min was employed to reach the calcination temperature of 200 °C, which was then kept constant for 3 h, then cooled with a ramp of 10 °C/min down to room temperature. 2.2 Composites characterization ζ-potential of water suspensions of the employed phases and the mixed suspensions was carried out in a Zetasizer Nano ZSP (Malvern Instruments) DLS/ELS (Dinamic Laser Scattering/Electrophoretic Light Scattering) instrument, automatically varying the pH of the suspension with the addition of either HCl or KOH 0.1 M water solutions. The measurement of ζ-potential was made via electrophoretic mobility in a Smoluchowski cell. Catalyst crystalline phases were identified by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), using a Bragg/Brentano diffractometer (X’pertPro PANalytical) equipped with an X’Celerator detector and Cu-Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation. The diffractograms were recorded in the 5° < 2θ < 80° range, with a 0.05°2θ acquisition step and 600 s acquisition time. Textural parameters (Specific Surface Area BET, Volume of pores and Diameter of pores) were assessed via N2 adsorption-desorption porosimetry using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020. Prior to cooling in a liquid nitrogen bath for N2 adsorption, samples were outgassed at 200 °C. Surface areas were determined by using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation assuming a cross section of 0.162 nm for the nitrogen molecule. The pore size distribution was obtained using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model. Temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was used to determine the density of acid sites. Firstly, 0.2 g of each catalyst was evacuated in a 30 STP mL/min He flow from room temperature to 500 °C, with a rate of 10 °C/min, and cooled under the same conditions to 100 °C during the so-called “degas” phase. The adsorption of NH3 followed, using 30 STP mL/min of 10 % NH3 in He flow for 20 min. Then, He flow was passed to purge the physiosorbed ammonia. Finally, temperature-programmed desorption was performed by heating the samples from 100 to 500 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to quantify the desorbed ammonia. The spray freeze-dried composite materials were observed via a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, Carl Zeiss Sigma NTS). Elemental analysis was performed using an energy-dispersive X-ray microanalyzer (EDX, INCA Energy 300, Oxford Instruments). The observed samples were fixed to aluminum stubs with conductive adhesive tape. Thermal behavior and polymer content of the composite materials was assessed by thermogravimetric analysis in a TA Instruments Q600 TGA instrument. Samples were loaded in an alumina sample holder and heated in air with a ramp of 10 °C/min up to 700 °C, then held for 30 min of isothermal step. The dry weight of the samples was assumed to be the weight measured at 200 °C, a temperature high enough to ensure water desorption even from the acid sites, but low enough to avoid any modification of the catalysts. The polymer content of each sample was calculated with the percentage weight loss between 200 °C and 700 °C. The density of Aquivion® Brønsted acid sites was measured both on the pure polymer and on the composite catalysts via solid-state NMR as reported in more detail elsewhere [40]. 19F MAS NMR spectra were recorded with a 400 MHz Agilent DD2 spectrometer, equipped with an HFXY T3 1.6 mm MAS probe spinning at 28 kHz. Bruker AVANCE III 400 WB spectrometer, equipped with a 4 mm standard probe spinning at 28 kHz. The quantification of LAS and BAS on the catalytic systems was carried out through 15N isotopically labelled pyridine adsorption at 25 °C by 15N MAS NMR following the same procedure described elsewhere [40]. 2.3 Catalytic tests The batch reactions were conducted in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave, equipped with a magnetic stirrer (IKA RCT Basic) and a heating mantle made of aluminum. To begin, 15 mL of isopropanol, 1 mmol of the substrate, and the required amounts of water and catalyst were added to the autoclave, which was then sealed. Nitrogen was introduced at 15 bar, and the system was purged by repeating this step three times to ensure the complete removal of air. Following this, the autoclave was pressurized with an additional 10 bar of nitrogen to minimize the risk of isopropanol evaporation during the heating process. The sealed autoclave was placed inside the heating mantle, and the temperature was gradually increased over 15 min until the desired temperature was reached. The reaction time was determined when the thermocouple inside the autoclave indicated a temperature within 1 °C of the target value. Once the reaction time was completed, the autoclave was rapidly cooled by immersion in an ice bath to stop the reaction. The resulting reaction mixture was carefully transferred to a 25 mL volumetric flask, and 20 μL of octane were added as an internal standard. Finally, the mixture was diluted to the calibration mark of the flask and analyzed using a Perkin-Elmer Clarus500 Gas Chromatograph, fitted with an Agilent HP-5 column. A 0.5 μL sample was injected into the system, with the injector temperature set to 250 °C. The oven temperature was initially held at 50 °C for the first 2 min, then increased at a rate of 10 °C/min until it reached 250 °C, where it was maintained for an additional 2 min. The instrument was equipped with a Flame Ionization Detector (FID), which was set to 250 °C. The flow rates were 50 mL/min for hydrogen and 450 mL/min for air. Furthermore, the lack of Lewis acidity makes it an ideal candidate for studying the effect of Aquivion's BAS. To verify the possibility of increasing the accessibility of the acid sites of the polymer, a series of Aquivion®/Silica composites with different polymer contents in the 20–40 wt% range were prepared by spray freeze drying ( Fig. 3a). To achieve a proper polymer dispersion over the oxide and optimize the synthetic procedure, ζ-potential measurements were taken for both Aquivion® and SiO2 suspensions (Fig. 3b). The same evaluation was also performed after preparing the composite material containing 30 % of Aquivion®. It is possible to notice that the ζ-potential behavior of the Aq/SiO2 30 % is more similar to the one of the pristine polymer. This suggests a similarity between the exposed surfaces of the two systems, which can be explained by a core-shell structure where Aquivion® encases oxide particles. To verify this hypothesis characterization by SEM of the composite materials was performed. By analyzing the SEM micrographs of Aq/SiO2 with increasing polymer content (Fig. S3) it can be seen that at high Aquivion® loadings (Aq/SiO2 40 %) the porosities in the structure can be covered and plugged by the polymer. This is also confirmed by the decrease of the specific surface area as reported in Fig. 3a. The 30 % loaded sample (Fig. 3c) displays a granular structure composed of spherical aggregates having a diameter distribution between 20 nm and 200 nm. The particles interior consists of an open cells foam-like matrix as shown in the higher magnification micrographs reported in Fig. S3. After having identified the composites’ structure, TGA analyses were carried out (Fig. 3d) to verify the real polymer content and assess the thermal behavior of the composite materials. It can be observed that, after the first low-temperature loss due to the water content, the Aquivion® decomposition initiated at around 250 °C and completed after 500 °C. The ratio between the weight loss in the 200–700 °C range and the weight at 200 °C revealed a polymer content very similar to the expected value (18 %, 29 % and 43 % compared to the expected values of 20 %, 30 % and 40 %). This qualifies the Spray Freeze Drying process as a reliable technique capable of producing materials with the expected compositions. N2 adsorption/desorption measurements allowed to obtain the pore size distribution (Fig. 3e) which consent to identify these materials as mesoporous, as well as the specific surface areas reported in Fig. 3a. Furthermore, a marked decrease in pore volume especially in the 2–20 nm range can be seen in Fig. 3e and the measured surface area of the composites was lower than the theoretical value obtained by calculating the weighted average SSA of the starting material (Fig. 5a). These results confirm an optimal polymer dispersion over the oxide and support the “plugging effect” of the Aquivion® as hypothesized from the SEM micrographs. Aquivion®/silica composites were tested as catalysts for the conversion of FAL to isopropyl levulinate (IPL) (Fig. 1) and compared with the catalytic performance of pure Aquivion® (Fig. 3f). This reaction was chosen as a relevant part of the whole cascade process that converts furfural to GVL as it requires BAS acidity, and it can be catalyzed by the polymer alone [44]. The first product, furfuryl isopropyl ether (FPE), deriving from the etherification of FAL with isopropanol, was shown to be the prevalent one (Fig. 3f). On the contrary, low selectivities in angelica lactones (AnL), produced in both the α and β isomers from the rearrangement of FAL, were obtained. The final product of this BAS-promoted reaction is isopropyl levulinate (IPL), obtained either via transesterification of AnL or via hydrolytic ring opening of FPE. The comparison of catalytic performance between catalysts indicates the fact that even if they were similarly active in the conversion of FAL, the product distribution differed significantly. The highest selectivity in the final product, IPL, was obtained working with Aq/SiO2 30 %. The latter showed the highest selectivity towards IPL (35 %), as well as the highest carbon balance (87 %). In particular, the higher AnL selectivity (8 %) coupled with a slightly lower conversion (95 %) might suggest a less prominent swelling of the polymer in this catalyst, which could lead to a lower retention of the molecules of interest on the surface of the catalyst. Conversely, pure Aquivion® showed the lowest carbon balance in the series (62 %); furthermore, the swelling of the pure polymer led to a highly adhesive gel phase and proved difficult to recover at the end of the reaction. 3.2 Physico-chemical effect of the metal oxides on the composite Two different oxides TiO2 (Aeroxide® P25, Evonik), and ZrO2 were used to prepare composite materials with Aquivion® in order to obtain materials with increasing Lewis acidity, capable of promoting the CTH steps [40]. The synthesis of zirconia is described in the Supporting Information, and its characterization is reported in Figures S1 and S2. Having previously identified Aq/SiO2 30 % as the most promising one among the composite with different compositions, Aq/TiO2 and Aq/ZrO2 were synthesized working with the same polymer content. As for the Aq/SiO2 composites, ζ-potential measurements were carried out as a function of the suspension pH on TiO2 and ZrO2 and their mixed suspensions. The results ( Fig. 4a-b) suggest the formation of an Aquivion® layer on the surface of the oxide in both cases. Indeed, the two mixed suspensions exhibited a behavior more similar to the one of the polymer than the one of the bare oxide, as previously shown for Aq/SiO2 (Fig. 3b). To further characterize the materials, SEM-EDX micrographs were taken for all samples (Fig. 4c-d). All the composites present a granular structure composed of spherical aggregates with a size ranging from about 30 µm to 300 µm. It was possible to achieve and preserve this particular morphology due to the spray freeze-drying process, through which water can be removed from the droplets of the starting suspension without altering its structure. From the N2 adsorption-desorption measurements carried out on the composites calcined at 200 °C, a consistent trend across the three series of catalysts could be identified (Fig. 5a). As observed for Aq/SiO2, the specific surface area (SSA) of each composite was lower than the weighted average of the SSA values of the two starting materials (dashed lines). This suggests an intimate contact between the two phases wherein Aquivion® covers the surface morphology of the metal oxide, lowering the surface area. Regarding Aq/SiO2 30 % and Aq/ZrO2 30 %, N2 adsorption/desorption analysis ( Fig. 5b-c) revealed type IV isotherms with H2 hysteresis, characteristic of mesoporous materials, with a hysteresis loop caused by pore blocking and capillary condensation phenomenon, usually bottleneck pores with narrowing and widening. Aq/TiO2 30 % also showed a type IV isotherm, with a rather large N2 uptake at high relative pressure, indicating a high average diameter meso-macroporosity. In the crystallites the bare TiO2 P25 does not contain pores. The porous structure can be formed by their aggregations and the average pore diameter coincides with TiO2 crystallite size. Like those reported in literature the TiO2 P25 used has a mean pore diameter of 15 nm. The hysteresis appears to be H1 type with a uniform porosity, usually due to parallel pores accessible from the outside. It appears that the porous structure formed of the aggregates of TiO2 crystallites is covered by the polymer. Only for the sample with SiO2, at low pressures, the two isotherms did not overlap because of the swelling of the Aquivion® which occurred in the presence of condensed nitrogen and gives different forms to the isotherm of adsorption and desorption. On the contrary, ZrO2 and TiO2 inhibited the swelling of the polymer due to the intimate contact achieved between the two phases of the materials, hence the overlap of the two isotherms at low pressure. TGA profiles (Fig. 5d) confirmed the reliability of the experimental procedure used, showing that the actual polymer content (between 28 % and 32 %) was in agreement with the theoretical one (30 %). Furthermore, the thermogravimetric analyses allowed to have an insight on the Aquivion® decomposition mechanism. It was observed a first weight loss below 100 °C assigned to the water content. The real decomposition was observed between 250 °C and 500 °C and it consisted in three distinct weight losses (Fig. 5e). As reported by Andreoli et al. for pure Aquivion®, the first loss at 320 °C could be attributed to the desulfonation of the material, while the second and the third one at 400 °C and 450 °C, are respectively ascribable to the decomposition of the side chains and the backbone of the polymer [45]. An important aspect that emerges from the measurements is the effect of the metal oxide on the polymer thermal stability. Comparing the profiles of the composite materials with the one of the pure Aquivion®, a shift of the desulfonation peak at lower temperatures was visible in the cases of Aq/TiO2 and Aq/ZrO2. On the other hand, the SiO2 seems to be able to stabilize the polymer so that the decomposition initiated at 394 °C instead of 320 °C. It is evident that the intimate contact of the two phases combined with the nature of the metal oxides are the causes of the polymer stabilization/destabilization. As shown by the NH3-TPD (Fig. 5f) both ZrO2 and TiO2 were characterized by their own acidity, with ZrO2 having the highest density of acid sites. It is indeed the acidity of the oxide that probably promoted the desulfonation of the Aquivion®. This explains why the Aq/ZrO2 showed the lowest decomposition temperature. Conversely, on SiO2, which has no acidity of its own, the stabilization effect due to the physical dispersion of Aquivion® prevails. We believe that by maximizing the dispersion of the polymer on the oxide surface, it is possible to minimize the autocatalytic degradation that inevitably occurs in Aquivion® bulk where the acid sites are closer together, therefore improving significantly the stability of the catalyst. Given the results above, the thermal behavior of the different composites was investigated. N2 physisorption was conducted on samples calcined at different temperatures ( Table 1). The thermogravimetric analysis allowed us to choose the proper calcination temperatures, resulting in a higher temperature range study for silica-based composites with respect to zirconia-based composites, which were subjected only to temperatures up to 250 °C. The calcination temperature of each sample was marked with the suffix “CSXXX”, where “CS” stands for “Calcined in Static air” and “XXX” is the calcination temperature in °C. The results highlight two different and opposite effects. The first one, observed in the ZrO2-based composite, consists of the pore blocking caused by Aquivion®, which became more prominent when the temperature increased its mobility. Indeed, between Aq/ZrO2 30 % CS200 and Aq/ZrO2 30 % CS250 the pore volume decreased from 0.14 cm3 g-1 to 0.08 cm3 g-1. On the contrary, the TiO2-based material, once reached 300 °C, displayed the freeing of pores because of the different porous structure, hence an increase of pore volume, due to Aquivion® decomposition. This can be observed between Aq/TiO2 30 % CS250 (0.20 cm3 g-1) and Aq/TiO2 30 % CS300 (0.41 cm3 g-1). According to the results above, zirconia-based composites could be calcined at 200 °C at most, given that at 250 °C structural changes already occurred. However, this is not the case for silica and titania-based spray-freeze dried composites, which underwent changes only at 300 °C (titania) or not at all (silica). To ensure that 200 °C was low enough to preserve the morphology of the spray-freeze dried catalysts, SEM images and SEM-EDX maps of the fresh and 200 °C treated samples were taken (Fig. S4, Fig. S5, and Fig. 4c-d). The good superimposability of the maps of fluorine (representing Aquivion®) and either titanium or zirconium (representing the respective oxides), confirms that no discernible transformations had occurred upon calcination. In order to further investigate the effect of the thermal treatment on the Aquivion®/oxide composites on the catalytic performance, Aq/oxide 30 % samples were employed in the valorization of FAL to GVL (Fig. 1a). After calcining the catalyst at different temperatures for 3 h, catalytic tests in the conversion of FAL to GVL were performed. Fig. 6a reports the results of catalytic tests carried out on Aq/SiO2 30 % calcined at different temperatures and tested in the same reaction conditions (120 °C for 2 h). The obtained trends confirm the thermal stability of the material suggested by TGA. Calcination up to 300 °C did not influence the catalytic performances of the silica-based catalyst, except for a small improvement from the uncalcined sample. In Fig. 6b, the study on the effect of calcination temperature on Aq/TiO2 30 %. Similarly to the silica sample, only small variations in the catalytic performances were visible upon calcination at 200 °C. Hence, the calcination temperature seems to be insignificant up to a certain point. However, in contrast to what was observed for the silica-based composite, above 250 °C there was a drastic change in catalytic performances: the conversion dropped to 20 %, IPL selectivity decreased to 14 % and FPE selectivity increased to 64 %. This suggests a deactivation of the catalyst probably due to the decomposition of the sulphonic groups of Aquivion®, which loses its acidic functions. Consequently, the further conversion of FAL to IPL was not achieved. These results suggest that a calcination temperature of 200–250 °C might be optimal. Regarding Aq/ZrO2 30 %, it could be observed in Fig. 7b that the catalyst deactivated above 250 °C, with conversion no longer reaching 100 % and the selectivity towards FPE increasing up to 50 %. Having the results been correlated with the Aquivion® acid loading assessed using 19F MAS NMR on a few selected samples (Fig. 7), it was possible to identify a sharp decrease in the number of Brønsted acid sites of Aquivion® from 1.20 mmol/g to 0.54 mmol/g where the lower corresponds to the deactivation observed in the catalytic process. The cause of the latter could be attributed to the thermal decomposition of Aquivion® that underwent desulfonation, losing the acid sites responsible for the reaction steps that lead from FAL to IPL, as previously shown by TGA (Fig. 5d). Once assessed the thermal stability of the Aquivion®/oxide composites, a calcination temperature of 200 °C was chosen as the desired temperature for all the composite materials. Afterward, the three calcined catalysts were tested in the same reaction conditions (1 mmol of FAL; FAL/BAS = 100 mol/mol; 15 mL of isopropanol; N2 pressure of 10 bar; Reaction temperature of 180 °C; Reaction time = 2 h) to compare their catalytic activity. The results reported in Fig. S6 showed that in every case, total conversion of FAL was reached and no FPE was formed. Working with Aq/SiO2 30 % the highest selectivities in AnL and IPL were obtained, respectively 20 % and 80 %, but no GVL was formed. Aq/TiO2 30 % behaves similarly to the silica composite, producing mostly IPL and AnL, even if with lower selectivities. On the contrary, Aq/ZrO2 30 % had the lowest selectivities in the two intermediates, accompanied by the highest selectivity in the final product (28 %). The reason may lie in the higher Lewis acidity of ZrO2 which is required to catalyze the conversion of the levulinate into the final product [40]. This study was further expanded to investigate the stability of the materials across different reaction cycles. The results for Aq/SiO2 30 %, Aq/TiO2 30 % and Aq/ZrO2 30 % (shown in Fig. 8a, b and c, respectively) show good stability across three catalytic tests for each of the materials, with a slight decrease in IPL selectivity that can be observed for Aq/ZrO2 30 %. This was attributed to fouling of the polymer [40], which can be reversed via regeneration with H2O2 [35]. In order to highlight the role of ZrO2 in the reaction pathway and to better identify the rate-limiting step in the process, an explorative test was carried out in the same experimental conditions by adding pure tetragonal ZrO2 to the reaction mixture, other than the catalyst Aq/ZrO2 30 % (Fig. S7). Increasing the total amount of LAS led to a more prominent conversion of IPL to GVL, decreasing the selectivity of the former to 30 %, and increasing the selectivity of the latter to 45 %. Nonetheless, a clear advantage of the composite materials over the physical mixture of the phases can be observed considering the turnover frequencies (TOF), especially over LAS. The addition of zirconia does increase the GVL selectivity, but the distance of those additional LAS from the rest of the catalyst lowers the overall TOF (Fig. 8d). This test revealed the LAS of zirconia as the rate-limiting factor in the catalytic system, but also highlighted the high activity of the BAS of Aquivion® and the clear advantage of these composite materials as catalytic systems. 4 Conclusions Through the Spray freeze-drying technique, a wide range of Aquivion® based composite materials was successfully synthesized, allowing a thorough investigation of the effect that each component exerts on the overall physico-chemical properties. SiO2 was chosen as an inert oxide to study the Aquivion® catalytic behavior in an SFD composite material. TiO2 and ZrO2 were selected due to their intrinsic acidic properties needed to carry out the cascade valorization of FAL to GVL. The actual formation of the composite materials, together with the intimate contact between Aquivion® and the three oxides were proved through different techniques. All the composites were analyzed by means of TGA, N2 adsorption-desorption, MAS NMR, and SEM-EDX analysis. The correlation between the obtained characterization results and catalytic performances unveils the role that each property of the materials plays in the reaction environment. Although SiO2 improved the thermal stability of the pristine polymer, it did not have any direct effect on the catalytic performances other than the dispersion of the polymer. ZrO2, instead, introduced strong Lewis acidity in the material, allowing Aq/ZrO2 30 % CS200 to produce GVL. Furthermore, the study of the thermal stability of three composite materials allowed to gain insight into the thermal decomposition and deactivation processes of such materials. These studies revealed an important effect of the dispersion of the polymer and the acidity of the support on the thermal stability of the composite, leading to the optimization of the thermal treatment procedure. In conclusion, this investigation sheds light on the various degrees of freedom offered by composite materials for catalytic purposes and their effectiveness in processes of importance for the development of green chemistry. coredata.dc:description: γ-Valerolactone (GVL) has transpired as a precursor to valuable chemicals, a fuel additive and an eco-friendly solvent. Herein, Aquivion®/oxide hybrid catalysts were prepared by an innovative spray freeze-drying method, tuning acid site distribution in the materials and exploring an approach to GVL synthesis from furfuryl alcohol (FAL) by employing non-noble metals. SiO2, TiO2 and ZrO2 were selected because of their increasing Lewis acidity, a key factor in promoting catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH). A thorough study on thermal stability through TGA, MAS NMR, porosimetry, SEM-EDX and experimental testing unveiled their resistance to thermal treatments and its influence on catalytic performances. In this study, it is shown how the optimal thermal treatment conditions for the composite materials vary depending on the acid properties of the supporting oxide.
